title: 115_hr5516
content: The "Investing in American Workers Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces the Employer-Provided Worker Training Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Employer-Provided Worker Training Credit under section 38 allows for a 20 percent credit on qualified training expenditures for non-highly compensated employees, excluding certain amounts. The term 'expenditures' excludes payments for meals, lodging, transportation, or other incidental services related to qualified training. Qualified training refers to programs leading to a recognized postsecondary credential, such as registered apprenticeships in emerging industries. The term 'expenditures' excludes payments for incidental services related to qualified training. Qualified training includes programs for recognized postsecondary credentials in emerging industries, approved by State apprenticeship agencies, listed under the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act, conducted by education institutions or labor organizations, and sponsored by employers, trade associations, industry partnerships, or labor organizations. The term 'emerging industry' refers to an industry comprising less than 30% of all civilian apprentices registered with the Department of Labor. 'Community college' is defined as a junior or community college. 'Labor organization' refers to a labor organization as defined in the Internal Revenue Code. 'Industry trade association' is an organization meeting specific criteria. An industry trade association is an organization exempt from taxation under the Internal Revenue Code and representing an industry. The terms 'area career and technical education school', 'recognized postsecondary credential', and 'industry or sector partnership' are defined by the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act. A non-highly compensated employee is an employee who does not earn a high salary. The text chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for an employee to qualify for a tax credit based on their compensation not exceeding $82,000 and their rate of compensation not exceeding $82,000 if applied to a full-time employee for a year. Special rules apply if the taxpayer has had no qualified training expenditures in any of the 3 preceding taxable years. The text chunk outlines the credit rate for adjusted qualified training expenditures, with rules similar to section 41(f) applying. Qualified small businesses or tax-exempt organizations can elect to apply the credit against payroll taxes. The text chunk explains the payroll tax credit portion of the credit determined under subsection (a) for a taxable year, with specific criteria for determining the amount. The text chunk discusses the election process for the business credit carryforward under section 39, specifying the amount of the credit and the deadline for making the election. The text chunk under section 6037 outlines limitations for making an election, including a maximum amount of $250,000 and restrictions on the number of taxable years for the election. The election can only be revoked with the consent of the Secretary. The election under this subsection for partnerships and S corporations must be made at the entity level. Aggregation rules apply, treating members of the same controlled group of corporations and trades or businesses under common control as a single taxpayer. The election under this subsection allows partnerships and S corporations to make the election at the entity level. Aggregation rules apply, treating members of the same controlled group of corporations and trades or businesses under common control as a single taxpayer. Special rules apply for separate elections and allocation of the $250,000 amount among taxpayers treated as a single entity. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to ensure compliance with the subsection's purposes. The subsection includes regulations to prevent avoidance of limitations and aggregation rules, minimize compliance burdens, and recapture benefits of credits in cases of adjustments. Section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new paragraph for the employer-provided worker training credit under section 45T. Section 280C is also amended to disallow deductions for expenses covered by the credit. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart. The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new item. Sec. 45T introduces the Employer-provided worker training credit, allowing a credit against the Alternative Minimum Tax. It also includes a Payroll Tax Credit for Worker Training Expenses under section 3111 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The taxpayer who elected under section 45S(e) can receive a credit against the tax imposed for the first calendar quarter after filing the return. The credit is limited to the tax imposed for the quarter on wages paid to all employees, with any excess credit carried over to the next quarter. The excess credit from one quarter can be carried over to the next quarter as a deduction. Small businesses with less than $5,000,000 in annual gross receipts can file tax returns in a simplified format. Regulations regarding postsecondary credentials must be established within a year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Labor, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, must issue regulations applying the definition of "recognized postsecondary credential" within one year of the Act's enactment. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after the Act's enactment.
